user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DirectoryClose:
```c
int32 OS_DirectoryClose(osal_id_t dir_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, dir_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_DirClose_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_DirectoryClose:
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_DirClose_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_dir_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_dir_table, *token);

    closedir(impl->dp);
    impl->dp = NULL;

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(OS_object_token_t *token, const osal_id_t *final_id)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;

    if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        /* nothing to do */
        return;
    }

    record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(token);

    /* re-acquire global table lock to adjust refcount */
    if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE || token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT)
    {
        OS_Lock_Global(token);
    }

    if (record->refcount > 0)
    {
        --record->refcount;
    }

    /*
     * at this point the global mutex is always held, either
     * from re-acquiring it above or it is still held from
     * the original lock when using OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL.
     *
     * If an ID update was pending (i.e. for a create/delete op)
     * then do the ID update now while holding the mutex.
     */
    if (final_id != NULL)
    {
        record->active_id = *final_id;
    }
    else if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE)
    {
        /*
         * If the lock type was EXCLUSIVE, it means that the ID in the record
         * was reset to OS_OBJECT_ID_RESERVED.  This must restore the original
         * object ID from the token.
         */
        record->active_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* always unlock (this also covers OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL case) */
    OS_Unlock_Global(token);

    /*
     * Setting to "NONE" indicates that this token has been
     * released, and should not be released again.
     */
    token->lock_mode = OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE;
}
...
int32 OS_NotifyEvent(OS_Event_t event, osal_id_t object_id, void *data)
{
    int32 status;

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler != NULL)
    {
        status = OS_SharedGlobalVars.EventHandler(event, object_id, data);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return status;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
/* always unlock (this also covers OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL case) */
    OS_Unlock_Global(token);
explanation:
I selected fragments that potentially mask unreachable code or branches that may never be taken in the provided call context and therefore should be investigated further:

- The final_id != NULL / else-if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE) block in OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish is suspicious because, in the provided code path (OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete -> OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish), final_id is always passed as the address of a local variable (i.e. non-NULL). If that is true for all callers in the project, the else-if branch can never be reached and would violate the unreachable-code rule. This fragment should be investigated across the whole project to see whether any caller ever passes final_id == NULL.

- The early return when token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE prevents the remainder of OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish from executing. This is a conditional return (not intrinsically a violation), but it makes the rest of the function unreachable for that token state; it should be checked that callers cannot erroneously call this function with lock_mode == NONE in contexts that expect the later actions to run.

- The unconditional OS_Unlock_Global(token) is marked "always unlock" in a comment, but whether the global lock is actually held at that point depends on prior logic (re-acquired only for some lock modes and possibly held originally for others). That line should be reviewed to ensure there is no code path where OS_Unlock_Global would be called without a corresponding lock (or where the call is unreachable), and to confirm the lock/unlock pairing is correct across all call sites.

Why other fragments were not selected:
- OS_DirectoryClose: straightforward sequence (get token, impl close, finalize) with no obvious unreachable statements; conditional/early return usage is standard and reachable depending on return_code.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById: contains an early return on failure from OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit; this is a normal error-path early exit and does not create unreachable code after an unconditional return in the same function.
- OS_DirClose_Impl: simple implementation that executes sequentially; no unreachable branches present.
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete: logic sets final_id based on operation_status and then calls transaction finish and possibly notifies. The branches are reachable depending on operation_status and are consistent with the intended behavior.
- OS_NotifyEvent: simple conditional invocation of the event handler; both branches are reachable depending on whether a handler is registered.

The three reported fragments should be examined in the context of the entire project (all callers of OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish and uses of final_id / token->lock_mode) to determine if any of the flagged code is in fact unreachable under all possible project usages.
